there's there's a secret in the name of landsat which is that it is a satellite program
that takes pictures of land so it's called landsat the usgs and nasa
come together to administer this program and it's it's the longest running earth observation program or satellite
satellite earth observation program uh in the world it's it's really become the gold standard for for how natural
resource imagery is is uh created and shared um it is what we would call big open
data and just like with a thousand genome story that i explained a minute ago to work with landsat data you need to
have the time and the capacity to download the data store it somewhere and
then have a computer that can actually do analysis on it and this is really difficult because landsat data is extremely rich so the
way the satellite works it's it covers the entire planet every 16 days and takes pic takes imagery um and really i
mean what it's doing this is at a sort of very mechanical level it's reflecting the light or it's measuring the light
that's reflected off the earth okay so it's very much sort of like what a what a camera does it it is a sensor that just detects
light um but landsat detects not only the visible light that we see you know red blue and green light but it also
detects infrared light and gathers information about the uh aerosols in the atmosphere as well as
thermal data and so each of these pictures like the one that you see there ends up being about a gigabyte of data um
and which you know it's pretty big so downloading an entire gigabyte of data uh
takes time and again if you want to do any sort of analysis at scale of landsat data you need to have a lot of storage
to be able to store you know gigabytes or terabytes of data or petabytes even of landsat data so not a lot of people
had this and so it ends up being time-consuming expensive so what we did is we created a landsat on aws
so we've committed to hosting up to a petabyte of landsat data the way we're doing it now is so the satellite's up
there it's taking pictures right now as those images are created we get them onto s3 as quickly as possible
another big distinction between the way landsat was traditionally acquired by people and the way that we provide it
is that to get a picture you'd have to download all of the bands of data so all the visible light all the infrared light the
thermal data everything like that which again i said is about a gigabyte what we do instead is we make each band
of each data which is just an individual file in an individual image we make that available as its own object on s3
and what this does is effectively creates a restful interface to get the data you just need a url you can get the
data that you want you can write scripts to get just the data that you want send that to ec2 do whatever kind of analysis
